**Description:** PMBOK Procurement Management Plan

## Procurement Management Plan: HR Insights Dashboard Project

**1. Introduction:**

This Procurement Management Plan outlines the strategy, processes, and procedures for acquiring goods and services required for the successful completion of the "HR Insights Dashboard" project.  This plan adheres to the PMBOK Guide (7th Edition) standards for procurement management.

**2. Project Scope and Procurement Needs:**

The project requires procurement of the following:

* **Software Licenses:**  Software for data visualization, dashboard creation, AI integration (for the HR AI Agent Maturity Assessment tab), and data analysis.  This includes potential cloud-based services.
* **Data Services (Optional):** If internal data is insufficient, external data services might be needed for benchmarking and trend analysis (especially for "Top HR Trends for 2025" and "Employee Value Proposition Assessment" tabs).
* **Consulting Services (Optional):**  Expert consultation might be required for specific aspects, such as AI model development or advanced data analysis techniques.
* **Hardware (Optional):**  Depending on internal resources, additional hardware might be necessary for data processing and storage.


**3. Make-or-Buy Analysis:**

| Item             | Make (In-house) | Buy (External) | Decision       | Rationale                                                                 |
|-----------------|--------------------|-----------------|-----------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| Software Licenses | High Cost, Time   | Lower Cost, Faster | Buy             | Access to specialized features and quicker implementation.                     |
| Data Services    | High Cost, Expertise | Potentially Lower Cost | Conditional Buy | Only if necessary data is not readily available internally.                    |
| Consulting Services | High Cost, Risk    | Lower Risk, Expertise | Conditional Buy | Only if specialized skills are unavailable internally.                         |
| Hardware         | High Capital Cost | Lower Initial Cost | Evaluate Options | Depends on existing infrastructure and budget; leasing may be a better option. |


**4. Procurement Strategy and Approach:**

The procurement strategy will be a combination of competitive bidding and negotiation, depending on the complexity and nature of the procurement item.  For software licenses, a competitive bidding process will be employed. For consulting services, a Request for Proposal (RFP) process followed by negotiation will be used.

**5. Contract Types and Procurement Methods:**

* **Software Licenses:**  Fixed-price contracts with clearly defined deliverables and service level agreements (SLAs).
* **Data Services:**  Time and materials contracts with pre-defined hourly rates and a cap on total expenditure.
* **Consulting Services:**  Fixed-price or Time and Materials contracts, depending on the scope and complexity of the work.

Procurement methods will include:

* Competitive bidding
* Request for Proposal (RFP)
* Negotiation

**6. Vendor Selection Criteria and Evaluation Processes:**

Vendor selection will be based on the following criteria:

* **Technical Capabilities:**  Experience and expertise in relevant technologies and domains.
* **Financial Stability:**  Demonstrated financial strength and stability.
* **References and Reputation:**  Positive feedback from previous clients.
* **Compliance:**  Adherence to relevant industry regulations and standards.
* **Pricing:**  Competitive and reasonable pricing structure.

Evaluation will involve a weighted scoring system, considering all criteria.

**7. Contract Management and Administration Procedures:**

* Establish a clear contract management process.
* Regular monitoring of vendor performance against contractual obligations.
* Timely communication and resolution of any disputes or issues.
* Regular progress meetings with vendors.
* Documentation of all communications and agreements.


**8. Risk Management for Procurement Activities:**

| Risk                               | Likelihood | Impact | Mitigation Strategy                                  |
|------------------------------------|------------|--------|------------------------------------------------------|
| Vendor delays                      | Medium     | High   | Include buffer time in schedule, strong contract clauses |
| Vendor performance issues           | Medium     | High   | Detailed performance metrics, regular monitoring      |
| Contract disputes                   | Low        | High   | Clear contract terms, legal review                    |
| Cost overruns                      | Medium     | High   | Thorough cost estimation, change control process       |
| Data security breaches             | Low        | High   | Secure contract clauses related to data security        |


**9. Procurement Performance Measurement and Control:**

Key performance indicators (KPIs) will include:

* Vendor on-time delivery
* Vendor adherence to budget
* Vendor quality of work
* Contract compliance
* Overall project cost and schedule impact


**10. Procurement Documentation and Record Keeping:**

All procurement-related documents, including contracts, correspondence, change orders, and performance evaluations, will be stored in a centralized repository.

**11. Vendor Relationship Management Strategies:**

Regular communication, performance feedback, and collaborative problem-solving will be employed to maintain positive vendor relationships.

**12. Contract Closure and Lessons Learned Processes:**

A formal contract closure process will be followed, including final acceptance of deliverables, payment processing, and archiving of all documentation. Lessons learned will be documented and used to improve future procurement processes.


This plan will be reviewed and updated as needed throughout the project lifecycle.  Any significant changes to the procurement strategy will require approval from the project sponsor and stakeholders.
